The Edge of Knowledge

A Documentary feature film about the quest to understand the black hole

Black holes pose puzzles at the frontier of physics, mathematics, astronomy, and philosophy. Following Stephen Hawking's last work, tracking the worldwide efforts of the Event Horizon Telescope, the film is an inquiry into the limits of what we can predict, what we can see, what we can know.

– about the filmmakers –

Peter Galison is a Pellegrino University Professor (of History of Science and of Physics) at Harvard University. Galison's previous film two films Secrecy (2008) and Containment (2015), both with Robb Moss. In 1997, he was awarded a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation Fellowship; his books include: Image and Logic: A Material Culture of Microphysics (1997); Einstein's Clocks, Poincaré's Maps: Empires of Time (2003), and (with L. Daston), Objectivity. He won the Abraham Pais Prize (American Physical Society, 2017). Galison's work also features artistic collaborations, including partnering (as dramaturg) with artist William Kentridge on a multi-screen installation, "The Refusal of Time." He is a co-founder of the Black Hole Initiative (Harvard), and a member of the Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration.

Chyld King is editor and co-producer of The Edge of Knowledge and is based in Boston, MA. He previously also edited and co-produced Galison and Moss's films Containment (2015) and Secrecy (2008), which premiered at the Full Frame and Sundance Film Festivals respectively. King worked for several years with filmmaker Errol Morris, and was one of the editors of Morris' Academy Award winning film The Fog of War. He has cut documentary projects for film and television, including episodes of God in America for PBS, American Experience's film The Amish, and other projects that have aired on networks such as PBS, IFC, and Bravo.
